Me sentí atraído por la armonía y la paz que reinaba allí, y comencé a entender por qué ella había querido que lo visitara. La gente del sitio me recibió con amabilidad y me invitaron a unirse a ellos en su ritual musical. Me senté en un círculo con ellos y, aunque al principio me sentí un poco incómodo, pronto me dejé llevar por la música y la emoción del momento. La arpa sonaba con una belleza que me conmovió profundamente, y pude sentir la conexión con la naturaleza y con los demás seres humanos que estaba experimentando. Fue una experiencia que nunca olvidaré, y me hizo ver la importancia de la música en la vida de las personas.

en_first_half: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome. By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then everybody was off to bed. I went up to my room with a piece of candle, and put it on the table. Then I set down in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn’t no use. I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead. The stars were shining, and the leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn’t make out what it was, and so it made the cold shivers run over me. Then away out in the woods I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell about something that’s on its mind and can’t
en_second_half: make itself understood, and so can’t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every night grieving. I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some company. Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it was all shriveled up. I didn’t need anybody to tell me that that was an awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and most shook the clothes off of me. I got up and turned around in my tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away. But I hadn’t no confidence. You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed a spider.

es_first_half: Un día la señorita Watson no paraba de meterse conmigo, y yo empecé a cansarme y a sentirme solo. Después llamaron a los negros para decir las oraciones y todo el mundo se fue a la cama. Yo me fui a mi habitación con un trozo de vela y lo puse en la mesa. Después me senté en una silla junto a la ventana y traté de pensar en algo animado, pero era inútil. Me sentía tan solo que casi me daban ganas de morirme. Las estrellas brillaban y las hojas de los árboles se rozaban con un ruido muy triste; allá lejos se oía un búho que ululaba porque se había muerto alguien y un chotacabras y un perro que gritaban que se iba a morir alguien más, y el viento trataba de decirme algo y yo no entendía lo que era, de forma que me daban calofríos. Después, allá en el bosque, oí ese ruido que hacen los fantasmas cuando quieren decir algo que están pensando y no pueden hacerse entender, de forma que no
es_second_half: pueden descansar en la tumba y tienen que pasarse toda la noche velando. Me sentí tan desanimado y con tanto miedo que tuve ganas de compañía. Luego se me subió una araña por el hombro y me la quité de encima y se cayó en la vela, y antes de que pudiera yo alargar la mano, ya estaba toda quemada. No hacía falta que me dijera nadie que aquello era de muy mal fario y que me iba a traer mala suerte, así que tuve miedo y casi me quité la ropa de golpe. Me levanté y di tres vueltas santiguándome a cada vez, y después me até un rizo del pelo con un hilo para que no se me acercaran las brujas. Pero no estaba nada seguro. Eso es lo que se hace cuando ha perdido uno una herradura que se ha encontrado, en vez de clavarla encima de la puerta, pero nunca le había oído decir a nadie que fuese la forma de que no llegara la mala suerte cuando se había matado a una araña.

tr_first_half: Bayan Watson nasihatlerini ve azarlarını peş peşe sıralarken kendimi giderek daha bitkin ve yalnız hissettim. Az sonra zenci köleleri içeri aldılar ve duaya başladılar, ardından da herkes yatağına çekildi. Bir mum alıp odama gittim ve mumu masanın üstüne koydum. Los chicos se miraron entre sí con una mezcla de emoción y miedo, sabiendo que estaban a punto de unirse a algo grande, pero también sabiendo que había una gran responsabilidad que les esperaba. Los chicos asintieron con la cabeza, decididos a cumplir con su juramento y proteger a su hermano. Mientras tanto, Tom les dio a cada uno un código de identificación que debían llevar siempre con ellos, y les explicó que debían estar en contacto constante entre sí a través de un canal secreto de comunicación. Los chicos se dispersaron, listos para comenzar su nueva vida como miembros de la banda, pero también sabiendo que había un gran desafío por delante. I didn't know what to wish for, and I was starting to feel like I was running out of time. Just as I was about to give up, the genie spoke up again. "Mortal, do not worry," she said. "You have all the time you need. Take your time, think carefully, and choose wisely. For your wishes will be granted, and they will change your life forever." I took a deep breath and closed my eyes, trying to clear my head. I thought about all the possibilities, all the things I could wish for. And then, suddenly, it came to me. I knew exactly what I wanted. I opened my eyes and looked at the genie, a smile spreading across my face. "I wish for the ability to heal any wound, to cure any sickness, and to bring happiness to those around me," I said, my voice filled with conviction. The genie nodded, a small smile playing on her lips. "Your wish is granted, mortal," she said. And with that, everything changed. I felt a surge of energy run through my body, and I knew that I had been given a great gift. I was no longer just a poor, struggling man. I was a healer, a bringer of hope and happiness. And I knew that I would use my gift to make the world a better place, one person at a time.

en_results_raw: The routine was monotonous, yet strangely soothing. I'd grown accustomed to the gentle lapping of the water against the shore, the soft chirping of birds, and the warmth of the sun on my skin. My days blended together in a haze of relaxation, with only the occasional snap of a twig or the splash of a fish breaking the silence. I'd lost all sense of time, and my clothes, once neat and tidy, now hung in tatters, a testament to my carefree existence. The widow's strict rules and routines seemed like a distant memory, a reminder of a life I'd left behind. I'd grown to appreciate the simple pleasures of life: a warm meal, a cool breeze, and the sound of the river flowing gently by. But as the days turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, I began to feel a stirring within me, a sense of restlessness that I couldn't quite explain. It was as if my body and mind were yearning for something more, something beyond the tranquil existence I'd created for myself. I tried to shake off the feeling, to tell myself that I was content, that I had everything I needed right here. But the sensation persisted, a nagging voice that whispered of adventure, of excitement, of a life beyond the quiet shores of the river.

es_results_raw: Al principio, su madre no estaba de acuerdo, pero luego recordó que su abuela siempre decía lo mismo. De repente, comenzaron a sentir un ligero frescor en el aire y el cielo se volvió gris. Jim se rió y dijo: "¡Veo que mi mamá tenía razón! Los pajaritos saben lo que dicen". Su madre sonrió y le dio un abrazo. Mientras tanto, el cielo se oscureció aún más y comenzaron a caer las primeras gotas de lluvia. La lluvia cayó suavemente al principio, pero pronto se convirtió en una lluvia intensa que los obligó a refugiarse en la casa. en_first_half: “Yes. You know that one-laigged nigger dat b’longs to old Misto Bradish? Well, he sot up a bank, en say anybody dat put in a dollar would git fo’ dollars mo’ at de en’ er de year. Well, all de niggers went in, but dey didn’t have much. I wuz de on’y one dat had much. So I stuck out for
en_second_half: mo’ dan fo’ dollars, en I said ’f I didn’ git it I’d start a bank mysef. Well, o’ course dat nigger want’ to keep me out er de business, bekase he says dey warn’t business ’nough for two banks, so he say I could put in my five dollars en he pay me thirty-five at de en’ er de year.
en_results: twenty dollars, en I got back forty. Den I went back de next day, en I put in twenty more, en I got back forty more. I kept on doin' dat till I had a whole heap of money. But den I got to thinkin', what's de point of all dis? I ain't no richer, I'm just richer in paper. I got a whole
en_results_raw: twenty dollars, en I got back forty. Den I went back de next day, en I put in twenty more, en I got back forty more. I kept on doin' dat till I had a whole heap of money. But den I got to thinkin', what's de point of all dis? I ain't no richer, I'm just richer in paper. I got a whole bunch of dollars, but I still ain't got nothin' to show for it. I'm still livin' in de same ol' cabin, still eatin' de same ol' food, still doin' de same ol' work. So I started to think, maybe I should just take my money out, en use it to buy somethin' real, somethin' dat'll make me happy. Maybe I should buy a new horse, or a new farm, or somethin' like dat. But den I thought, what if I lose it all? What if de bank fails, or I get robbed, or somethin'? I'd be back to square one, en I'd be worse off den I was before. So I kept on puttin' my money in, hopin' dat one day I'd be able to get out, en live de life I really wanted. But dat day never came, en I'm still stuck here, wonderin' what could've been.

en_first_half: This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot high. We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep and the bushes so thick. We tramped and clumb around all over it, and by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top
en_second_half: on the side towards Illinois. The cavern was as big as two or three rooms bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it. It was cool in there. Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.
en_results: The cavern was a massive opening in the side of the hill, partially hidden by the dense foliage that surrounded it. As we stepped inside, the air grew cooler and the sounds of the forest grew muffled, replaced by the gentle dripping of water somewhere in the depths of the cavern.
en_results_raw: The cavern was a massive opening in the side of the hill, partially hidden by the dense foliage that surrounded it. As we stepped inside, the air grew cooler and the sounds of the forest grew muffled, replaced by the gentle dripping of water somewhere in the depths of the cavern. The interior was surprisingly spacious, with a high ceiling that disappeared into darkness, and a large, flat area of smooth rock that seemed to have been worn down by the constant flow of water over the years. We made our way deeper into the cavern, our footsteps echoing off the walls as we explored the vast, mysterious space. The air was musty and damp, filled with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves. As we walked, the sound of running water grew louder, and we caught glimpses of a small stream that flowed through the cavern, its source and destination unknown. We followed the stream, our hearts racing with excitement and a touch of fear, as we wondered what other secrets the cavern might hold. The darkness seemed to press in around us, but we pressed on, our flashlights casting eerie shadows on the walls as we delved deeper into the unknown. The stream led us to a small waterfall, where the water cascaded down a rocky slope, creating a misty veil that surrounded us like a mystical aura. De repente, él se levantó y dijo: "Vamos a bajar al pueblo a buscar algo de comer". Le seguí y juntos comenzamos a bajar el cerro, hablando y riendo mientras caminábamos. Al llegar al pueblo, nos dirigimos a la tienda de abarrotes y compramos un poco de pan, queso y embutidos. Mientras caminábamos de regreso a la cima del cerro, mi amigo me preguntó si quería ir con él a la fiesta de cumpleaños de su hermana que se celebraba esa noche. Le dije que sí, y él se rió y me dijo que estaba seguro de que mi presencia sería un gran éxito. Me sentí un poco nervioso, pero también emocionado de la idea de ir a la fiesta y conocer a su familia. Al llegar a la cima del cerro, nos sentamos en la hierba y nos quedamos mirando el paisaje mientras esperábamos a que se hiciera de noche. El sol se puso completamente y el cielo se volvió una bóveda de estrellas brillantes. Mi amigo me dio un golpecito en el hombro y me dijo: "Vamos, vámonos a la fiesta". Le seguí y juntos comenzamos a bajar el cerro de nuevo, esta vez hacia la casa de su hermana. Al llegar, nos encontramos con una multitud de personas bailando y riendo. Mi amigo me presentó a su familia y a sus amigos, y me sentí un poco incómodo al principio, pero pronto me relajé y me uní a la fiesta. La música era alegre y la gente era amable, y pronto me sentí como si fuera parte de la familia. Pasamos la noche bailando, riendo y comiendo, y yo me sentí agradecido de haber aceptado la invitación de mi amigo. La fiesta fue una noche inolvidable y me hizo sentir conectado con la gente y con la comunidad. Al final de la noche, mi amigo me dio un abrazo y me dijo: "Gracias por venir, eres un verdadero amigo". Me sentí conmovido por sus palabras y le dije que siempre estaría allí para él. Y así, terminó la noche, pero la amistad y la conexión que habíamos compartido serían recordadas por mucho tiempo. La luna llena brillaba en el cielo, iluminando el camino de regreso a casa, y yo me sentí agradecido por haber tenido la oportunidad de compartir esa noche con mi amigo. La experiencia me había enseñado que la amistad y la conexión con los demás pueden ser verdaderamente transformadoras y que a veces, las decisiones que tomamos pueden llevarnos a lugares inesperados y maravillosos. Y así, me quedé dormido con una sonrisa en el rostro, sabiendo que la amistad y la conexión que había compartido esa noche serían un recuerdo que me acompañaría por mucho tiempo. La mañana siguiente, me desperté con el sol brillando en mi rostro y el sonido de los pájaros cantando en los árboles. Me sentí renovado y listo para enfrentar el día, sabiendo que la amistad y la conexión que había compartido la noche anterior me habían dado una perspectiva nueva y una sensación de conexión con el mundo que me rodeaba

en_first_half: Next morning I said it was getting slow and dull, and I wanted to get a stirring up some way. I said I reckoned I would slip over the river and find out what was going on. Jim liked that notion; but he said I must go in the dark and look sharp. Then he studied it over and said, couldn’t I put on some of them old things and dress up like a girl? That was a good notion, too. So we shortened up one of the calico gowns, and I turned up my trouser-legs to my knees and got into it. Jim
en_second_half: hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit. I put on the sun-bonnet and tied it under my chin, and then for a body to look in and see my face was like looking down a joint of stove-pipe. Jim said nobody would know me, even in the daytime, hardly. I practiced around all day to get the hang of the things, and by-and-by I could do pretty well in them, only Jim said I didn’t walk like a girl; and he said I must quit pulling up my gown to get at my britches-pocket. I took notice, and done better.

en_results_raw: <output>The calico gown was a bit too short, but it would have to do. I tied a handkerchief around my head, and Jim helped me tie a big bow under my chin. He said I looked just like a girl, and I had to admit, I didn't look half bad. I felt a little silly, but it was worth it if it would help us get some information. Jim gave me a small basket to carry, and we set off towards the river. The sun was just starting to rise, casting a golden glow over the landscape. We moved quietly, trying not to make any noise as we made our way down to the water's edge. The river was calm and peaceful, with a few birds singing in the trees along the bank. I took a deep breath, feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness. Jim gave me a reassuring nod, and we slipped into the water, wading across to the other side. Once we reached the middle, we stopped and looked around, taking in our surroundings. The opposite bank was shrouded in mist, but we could see the faint outline of a small village in the distance. We waited for a few moments, listening for any signs of life, before making our way towards the village. As we walked, the mist began to clear, revealing more of the village's layout. We saw a few buildings, some smoke rising from the chimneys, and people starting to stir. I felt a surge of excitement - we were getting close to finding out what was going on. Jim and I exchanged a look, and then we continued on, trying to blend in and gather as much information as possible. We walked through the village, taking in the sights and sounds, and trying to act like we belonged. The villagers seemed friendly, but we knew we had to be careful not to arouse suspicion. We stopped at a small market stall, where the vendor was selling fresh produce and baked goods. I tried to act nonchalant, browsing through the wares while Jim asked the vendor a few questions. The vendor seemed friendly, but I could tell he was watching us closely. I made a mental note to be more careful, and we continued on our way, trying to gather as much information as possible. As we walked, we came across a group of people gathered around a large tree. They were talking in hushed tones, and I could tell they were discussing something in secret. Jim and I exchanged a look, and then we crept closer, trying to listen in without being noticed. The conversation was about a group of strangers who had been seen in the area, and how they were causing trouble. The villagers were worried, and I could tell they were on high alert. I felt a shiver run down my spine - could these strangers be connected to what was going on in our town? I looked at Jim, and he nodded, his eyes locked on mine. We knew we had to be careful, and we continued on our way, trying to gather more information. As we left the village, I couldn't shake the feeling that we were getting close to the truth. We made our way back to the river, and waded back across, careful not to make any noise. Once we reached the other side, we sat down on a rock, taking a moment to process what we had learned. Jim turned to me, his eyes serious. "What do you think it means?" he asked. I shook my head, unsure. "I don't know, but I think we're getting close to something big." Jim nodded, and we sat in silence for a moment, thinking. Then he spoke up. "We need to get back to the others and tell them what we've learned." I nodded, and we stood up, making our way back through the forest. As we walked, I couldn't shake the feeling that we were being watched. I glanced around, but saw nothing out of the ordinary. I pushed the feeling aside, focusing on the task at hand. We finally reached the others, and I filled them in on what we had learned. They listened intently, their faces serious. When I finished, they nodded, and we began to discuss our next move. We knew we had to be careful, but we were determined to get to the bottom of things. We spent the rest of the day gathering more information, trying to piece together the puzzle. As the sun began to set, we decided to head back to our camp, tired but determined. We knew we still had a long way to go, but we were one step closer to the truth. As we walked, I couldn't help but feel a sense of pride - we had taken a risk, and it had paid off. We were getting closer to the truth, and we were determined to see it through. We reached the camp, and the others were relieved to see us

Jim spotted a small island up ahead, and he steered the raft towards it, the current carrying us towards the shore. We landed with a thud, and I jumped off, my feet sinking into the mud. Jim followed close behind, and we started to make our way through the underbrush, our hearts still racing from the excitement of the day. We walked for what felt like hours, the darkness closing in around us, until we finally came to a small clearing. In the center of the clearing stood an old cabin, its door creaking in the wind. We approached it slowly, our senses on high alert, and I pushed open the creaky door, my heart pounding in my chest. We’d got to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves. So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, too—seemed a week before we got to the stern. No sign of a boat. Jim said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t hardly any strength left, he said. But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure. So on we
en_second_half: prowled again. We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water. When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough! I could just barely see her. I felt ever so thankful. In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened. The thought sent a shiver down my spine, and I glanced nervously at Jim, who was rowing steadily, his face set in a determined expression. I knew he was a skilled oarsman, but I also knew that even the most skilled person could make mistakes. The sun was beginning to set, casting a golden glow over the water, but I couldn't shake off the feeling of unease that had settled in the pit of my stomach. As we glided further away from the shore, the trees seemed to grow taller and the air grew thick with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves. I felt a sense of disconnection from the world we had left behind, and a sense of uncertainty about what lay ahead. The silence between Jim and me was oppressive, punctuated only by the creaking of the oars and the gentle lapping of the water against the hull of the raft. I knew we had to keep moving, but a part of me longed to turn back, to return to the safety and familiarity of our old life. en_results_raw: The shore, she'd come after me herself. I took a deep breath and plunged into the water, the icy coldness hitting me like a slap in the face. The current was strong, but I kicked hard and stroked with all my might, my eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of rescue. The sun was high overhead, beating down on me like a hammer, and I could feel my energy waning. I'd been swimming for what felt like hours, but I knew I had to keep going. I thought of my family, of pap and the others back on the boat, and I knew I had to get help. I spotted a small island in the distance, its sandy beach a welcome sight. I swam towards it with renewed determination, my strokes growing stronger with each passing moment. As I reached the shore, I collapsed onto the sand, exhausted but relieved. I knew I had to find shelter and start a fire, and then I could send up a signal to attract the attention of any passing ships. I looked around, taking in my surroundings, and spotted a small cave nearby. I stumbled towards it, my legs shaking beneath me. Inside, I found a small fire pit, and I quickly got to work, gathering dry wood and kindling. I lit a fire, and the warmth and light it provided was a welcome comfort. I knew I had to stay here until help arrived, and I was determined to survive. I sat by the fire, watching the flames dance and listening to the sound of the waves crashing against the shore. As the sun began to set, I knew I had to find food and water. I scanned my surroundings, looking for any signs of life. That's when I saw it - a small stream running through the island, its crystal clear water a lifeline in my time of need. I followed it, my thirst and hunger growing with each step. As I walked, I noticed the stream led me to a small clearing, and in the center of it stood a small tree, its branches heavy with fruit. I approached it cautiously, my stomach growling with anticipation. I reached out and plucked a few of the fruit, and took a bite. The sweetness exploded in my mouth, and I felt a surge of energy. I ate as much as I could, and then I followed the stream further, searching for more food and water. As the night began to fall, I found a small patch of coconuts, and I gathered as many as I could carry. I returned to the cave, my belly full and my thirst quenched. I settled in for the night, the sound of the waves and the warmth of the fire lulling me into a deep sleep. I knew I had to be careful, that I had to stay alert and watch for any signs of danger. But for now, I was safe, and that was all that mattered. As I drifted off to sleep, I knew I would face whatever challenges came my way, and I was determined to survive.

He had tried to brush it off as mere fantasy, but the more he thought about it, the more he became convinced that it was more than just a dream. en_results_raw: The raft had drifted a little ways from the shore, and I could see the boys' figures growing smaller and smaller as they disappeared into the trees. I felt a pang of regret and loneliness wash over me, and I wondered if I'd ever see them again. I thought about all the times we'd had together, the adventures we'd shared, and the laughter we'd enjoyed. I realized that I'd been so caught up in my own selfish desires that I'd hurt the people who mattered most to me. I thought about what my father had always said, that "when you're in a tight spot, you'll find out who your real friends are." I wondered if I'd ever find out who my real friends were, or if I'd be left to face the consequences of my actions alone. The sun was starting to set, casting a golden glow over the water, and I felt a sense of unease settle in. I knew I had to make things right, but I didn't know where to start. I looked out at the raft, and for a moment, I thought I saw a figure standing on the shore, watching me. But when I looked again, it was just a tree branch swaying in the breeze. I took a deep breath and tried to calm myself down, but my mind was racing with thoughts of what could have been and what might still be. I knew I had to keep moving forward, but I wasn't sure where I was going or what lay ahead. The raft drifted further and further away from the shore, and I was left with nothing but my thoughts to keep me company.

El tipo se llamaba Cipote y parecía que había vivido toda su vida en la esclavitud, porque no sabía hacer nada más que trabajar y callar. Cada día, Buck se quejaba de la suerte que había tenido al recibir a Cipote como su esclavo, y yo me reía de sus quejas porque sabía que Cipote era un tipo muy valioso a pesar de su edad. Aunque no era tan listo como mi negro, Cipote tenía una gran experiencia y sabía hacer cosas que yo ni siquiera sabía que existían. Por ejemplo, podía hacer un fuego con solo un poco de madera seca y un trozo de hierba seca, y podía preparar una comida deliciosa con solo unos pocos ingredientes. Buck se sorprendía cada vez que Cipote hacía algo que él no podía hacer, y yo me reía de su sorpresa porque sabía que Cipote era un tipo muy especial. A pesar de que Cipote era viejo y cansado, siempre estaba dispuesto a trabajar y a ayudar a Buck, y Buck se daba cuenta de que no podía vivir sin él. Pero siempre, después de la tormenta, el río volvía a ser tranquilo, y la balsa se convertía en un refugio seguro, un lugar donde podíamos descansar y disfrutar de la belleza del mundo que nos rodeaba. Justo cuando pensaba que iba a poder escapar, escuché un grito en la distancia, y me di la vuelta para ver a los dos hombres corriendo hacia mí, pero esta vez con una velocidad y determinación que me hizo sentir que no había escapado de nada. Mi instinto me decía que debía seguir remando, pero mi mente me decía que tal vez debería detenerme y hablar con ellos, y saber qué querían. La duda me paralizó por un momento, y mi remo se detuvo en el agua, y me quedé flotando en el medio del arroyo, esperando a que los tres hombres se acercaran a mí.

es_results_raw: completion>...ante la mirada de la señora de la casa, que no ha cesado de llorar desde que se enteró de la noticia. La casa, que siempre había sido un refugio de amor y tranquilidad, ahora se había convertido en un lugar de angustia y desesperanza. El señor Aguassucias, un hombre de gran corazón y fuerte carácter, se sentía abrumado por la responsabilidad de afrontar los problemas que se avecinaban. Su esposa, la señora Aguassucias, se había convertido en una sombra de su antigua persona, y su hija, la pequeña Sofía, no podía entender por qué su padre no podía hacer desaparecer los problemas con un simple gesto de la mano. El señor Aguassucias sabía que no era tan fácil, que la vida no era un juego de cartas en el que se podían cambiar las reglas a voluntad. Pero ¿qué podía hacer? ¿Qué podía hacer para hacer que todo volviera a la normalidad? La incertidumbre lo consumía por dentro, y su mente se llenaba de preguntas sin respuesta. ¿Qué iba a pasar con su familia? ¿Qué iba a pasar con su negocio? ¿Qué iba a pasar con su vida? Las preguntas se multiplicaban en su cabeza, y el señor Aguassucias se sentía cada vez más abrumado. Pero no se rindió. No se rindió porque sabía que tenía que seguir adelante, que tenía que encontrar una solución a los problemas que lo rodeaban. Y así, con la determinación en el corazón, se puso a trabajar en busca de una salida a la situación.

en_results_raw: The rain was warm, and the sound of it on the leaves was soothing, so I laid outside, listening to the patter and watching the raindrops fall through the fireflies that were still dancing around the clearing. The fire had burned down to embers, but the warmth it had left behind was still radiating, and I felt it seep into my bones as I lay there. I was half asleep, my mind drifting in and out of consciousness, when I heard a faint rustling in the bushes nearby. I sat up, my heart beating a little faster, and peered into the darkness, trying to see what was making the noise. It sounded like something was moving through the underbrush, its branches snapping and leaves crunching beneath its feet. I strained my ears, trying to pinpoint the sound, and suddenly it stopped. The silence was oppressive, and I felt a shiver run down my spine as I wondered what could be lurking just out of sight. I lay back down, trying to calm myself, but my mind was racing with all sorts of possibilities. Was it a wild animal, or something more sinister? I didn't know, but I knew I had to be careful. I lay there for what felt like hours, my senses on high alert, waiting for whatever it was to make another move. But the silence remained, and eventually I drifted off to sleep, lulled by the sound of the rain.

Me pareció que estaban discutiendo sobre qué hacer con la lluvia, pero no podía escuchar bien lo que decían. De repente, Jim se levantó y se acercó a mí, sonriendo. es_first_half: —Me siento tan mal porque he oído allá en la orilla algo así como un golpe, o un portazo, hace un rato, y me recuerda la vez que traté tan mal
es_second_half: a mi pequeña Lizabeth. No tenía más que cuatro años y le dio la ascarlatina y las pasó muy mal; pero se puso güena y un día voy y digo, dije:
es_results: que a mi hermano, y ahora él no habla conmigo desde hace años. Me pregunto si será algo grave, si alguien estará herido, o si es solo un perro
es_results_raw: que a mi hermano, y ahora él no habla conmigo desde hace años. Me pregunto si será algo grave, si alguien estará herido, o si es solo un perro que ha encontrado un hueso. Me levanto de la cama y me dirijo hacia la orilla del río, sintiendo un nudo en el estómago, y un sentimiento de culpa que me hace sentir aún peor. Al llegar allí, veo que la orilla está desierta, pero veo algo que me hace detenerme en seco: un bote de remos, con un remo suelto, y un pedazo de ropa que cuelga en la rama de un árbol. Me acerco a investigar, y veo que es una chaqueta de mi hermano, y un trozo de su camisa. Me siento como si me hubieran dado un golpe en el pecho, y no puedo respirar. ¿Qué ha pasado con mi hermano? ¿Dónde está? ¿Está vivo? Me quedo allí, con la chaqueta de mi hermano en mis manos, sintiendo como si mi mundo se estuviera derrumbando a mi alrededor.

en_results_raw: <output>The room was small and dimly lit, with a single window that let in a faint ray of moonlight, casting an eerie glow on the walls. I fumbled through my pockets, searching for a match or a candle, but all I could find was a small piece of flint and a piece of steel. I struck the flint against the steel, and a spark flew onto a piece of dry wood on the floor, igniting a small flame. I held the flame to a nearby candle, and it flickered to life, casting a warm glow over the room. The air was thick with dust, and cobwebs hung from the corners of the ceiling, but I didn't notice any signs of recent occupation. I began to search the room more thoroughly, my eyes scanning the shelves and the dresser, but there was nothing out of the ordinary. I moved on to the bed, lifting up the mattress and checking underneath, but it was empty. I was starting to get frustrated, wondering if I had been wrong about the king's money being here. Just as I was about to give up, I heard a faint creaking sound coming from the closet. It was a small, narrow space, but it was the only place left to search. I pushed the door open, and a musty smell wafted out. The closet was cramped, with rows of old clothes and a small trunk in the corner. I lifted the lid, and a faint glint of gold caught my eye. I reached in, and my fingers closed around a small pouch filled with coins. It was the king's money, all right. I felt a surge of excitement, but it was short-lived. As I reached for the pouch, I heard footsteps coming from outside the room. I froze, my heart pounding in my chest. Someone was coming. I quickly hid the pouch and waited, holding my breath as the door creaked open. A figure loomed in the doorway, and I prepared myself for the worst. But to my surprise, it was only the king himself, a look of concern etched on his face. "What are you doing in here?" he asked, his voice low and even. I tried to think of an excuse, but my mind went blank. I could only stare at him, my eyes wide with fear. The king took a step closer, his eyes narrowing. "I could have sworn I locked this door," he said. I swallowed hard, trying to come up with something, anything, to say. But the words stuck in my throat. The king's eyes seemed to bore into my soul, and I felt a chill run down my spine. I knew I was in trouble. I was caught red-handed, and I had no idea how I was going to get out of this one. The king's face darkened, and I steeled myself for the worst. But just as he was about to speak, a loud crash echoed from downstairs, followed by the sound of shouting and footsteps. The king's head jerked up, and he turned to me. "What was that?" he asked, his voice laced with concern. I shook my head, just as confused as he was. I thought about trying to sneak back to the graveyard and dig up the money myself, but I knew that was a fool's errand - I'd never be able to get in and out without being seen. And then I thought about telling Mary Jane the truth, but I knew she'd be just as mad as a wet hen if she found out I'd been lying to her. I was in a regular pickle, and I didn't know how to get out of it. I paced back and forth for what felt like hours, trying to think of a solution, but my mind was as stuck as a rusty gate. Just when I thought I was going to go plumb crazy, I heard a noise outside my window. It was a low, muffled sound, like someone was trying not to be heard. I froze, my heart pounding in my chest, and listened intently. The sound came again, this time a little louder, and I knew I had to investigate. I crept over to the window and peeked out into the darkness, trying to see who or what was making the noise. And that's when I saw him - a figure, tall and gaunt, standing in the shadows, watching me. I felt a chill run down my spine as our eyes met, and I knew I was in for a world of trouble.

Podría intentar hablar con el rey y explicarle la situación, pero sabía que él no me creería. Me sentí abrumado por la desesperación y la impotencia. ¿Qué podía hacer? Me quedé sentado en la oscuridad, intentando pensar en una solución, pero mi mente estaba en blanco. De repente, oí un ruido fuera de la habitación y me di cuenta de que alguien estaba entrando. Me quedé quieto, esperando a ver quién era. Era uno de los guardias del rey, con una expresión seria en su rostro. Me pregunté qué quería. ¿Podría ser que hubiera descubierto mi plan? Me sentí un escalofrío recorrer mi espalda al pensar en la posibilidad de ser descubierto. El guardia se acercó a mí y me habló en voz baja. "Señor, el rey quiere hablar con usted". Me levanté de la cama y seguí al guardia hacia la habitación del rey, sintiendo un presentimiento de que mi suerte estaba cambiando. Al entrar en la habitación, vi al rey sentado en su trono, con una expresión seria en su rostro. Me di cuenta de que algo estaba mal. ¿Qué quería el rey? Me acerqué a él y me incliné para escuchar lo que tenía que decirme. "Señor", dijo el rey, "he sabido que ha estado buscando un lugar para esconder algo. ¿Qué es lo que ha estado buscando?" Me quedé sorprendido por la pregunta. ¿Cómo había descubierto el rey mi plan? Me di cuenta de que no podía mentirle, así que le dije la verdad. "Señor, he estado buscando un lugar para esconder un tesoro que me pertenece a mí". El rey me miró con una expresión de sorpresa y luego se rió. "Un tesoro, ¿eh? ¿Qué tipo de tesoro?" But now, as I stood there, I couldn't shake the feeling that I'd been caught, that the undertaker had somehow seen me, that he was just playing a waiting game. We walked for a while, the only sound being the crunch of leaves and snapping of twigs beneath our feet. The trees seemed to close in around us, their branches creaking ominously in the gentle breeze. Tom stopped suddenly, his hand raised in a warning gesture, and I froze, my heart pounding in my chest. "What is it?" I whispered, my voice barely audible over the rustling of the leaves. Tom's eyes scanned the darkness, his face set in a determined expression. "I thought I saw something moving," he whispered back, his voice low and urgent. I strained my eyes, but saw nothing. "It's probably just a raccoon or a stray animal," I said, trying to reassure him. But Tom's expression didn't change, and I could tell he was still on high alert. We stood there for a moment, frozen in silence, waiting to see if whatever it was would reappear. The minutes ticked by, and the only sound was the distant hooting of an owl. I was about to speak again when Tom's hand dropped, and he nodded towards a small clearing up ahead. "Let's go," he whispered, and we moved forward, our footsteps quiet on the forest floor.

I took a bite, the corn-pone crumbling in my mouth, the butter melting on my tongue, and for a moment, I was transported back to a time when life was simpler, and the only worry was what to do with the day ahead. But as I chewed, my mind began to wander, and I thought of all the things that could go wrong, of all the things that I needed to do, and my stomach began to twist with anxiety. I pushed the thoughts aside, and took another bite, the sweetness of the corn-pone and the richness of the butter momentarily distracting me from my worries. But as I looked around the kitchen, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched, and I knew I needed to get back to bed, and fast.
